713044f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street - 6th Avenue
713044f-a.text:
12nd Street, west from and including Sixth Avonue, showing the new
Bush Terminsl Building on the south side of the street.
The building whose roof is shown in the right foreground is the
Bryant Park Arcade at the N.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and 42nd
Street; it will later be rcplaced by Stern Brothers' new building.
About 1923.
Ewing Galloway.

730135f-b.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.
730135f-b.text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, 'est 40's and 5C's: Vi: w 1
is northwestwarc across the area lying between Sixth Avenue
and Broadway anc between 42nd and 49th 'treet. In the lower
left corner is the roof of the Hippodrome and the Sixth
Avenue ''El''. The Botel Astor is on the upper left hand corner.
View 2 is northwestward across the West 5C's seen from Radio
City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential
hotels on Central Park South.
P. L. Sperr  View 11 June 24, 193
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: December 1, 1932

717926f.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 42nd Street
717926f.text:
Bryant Park, northwestern quarter, looking north towards W. 42nd
Street. Sixth Avenue is on the left and does not appear. The white
building on the right is Stern's Department Store. Individuals in
the foreground are relaxing from the summer heat.
Probably Summer 1925
Ewing Galloway
NO REPRODUCTIONS

April 7, 1936.
Mr. Schwartn, New York Public Library.

709492f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 42nd Street (West)
709492f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West
42nd Street, and showing this thoroughfare subsequent
to the demolition of the elevnted line identified with
same. Shortly to follow will be the old Hippodrome
building. This cleared site from 43rd to 44th Stre t's
will be used as an auto parking lot. Stern's Department
Store at the right and in the background are Roclefeller
Center buildings. Subway construction is progressing
at this date.
Views 1, 2: May 6, 1939
View 3: September 8, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRO5UCTIONS

709491f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 42nd Street,
showing the diatinctive Hippodrome between 43rd and 44th
Stroet's. The photographer's vantage point is the Wurlitzer
Building,from hich he is viewing northeastward. Note the
Sixth Avenue Elevated.
Vew 2 is from the 42nd Street station of
same while No. 3 is from the street level. In these
views, one observes constructional details of the
towering Rockefeller Center.

View 2: June 8, 1932
View 3: May 1, 1933
P. L. Srerr

717918f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - [42nd Street]
717918f-b.text:
(1)
Demolition of the Federal Hall repplica, Bryant Park, east-center;

(2)

May 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The center part of the Park, seen from Sixth Avenue, showing the
remodelling of the Park in process under the regime of Com-
aissioner Robert Moses, New York's first city-wide Commissioner
of Parks. Prior to an enabling act passed in 1934 by the
State Legislature, there was a eeparate Park Commissioner for
each bonough.
August 20, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

709482f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 42nd Street (West)
709482f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing portions
of the ''El'' station at that point, prior to demolition.
This, by personal observation on the part of the writer,
will occur in April of this year.
The photographer is on the southbound platform and
he is viewing across the tracks towards the opposite one.
The stairway details are of his vantage point. The build-
ings here shown are at the N. W. corner.
March, 1939
Views 1-2
Wm. Herries
MA BE REPRODUCED

717895f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 42nd Street
717895f-a.text:
The Crystal Palace, Sixth Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 40th
Streets. The idea of an industrial exposition housed in a building
of glass and iron originated in London with the Crystal Palace of
1851, in Hyde Park. The New York building, however, was smaller
than its London predecessor, and entirely different in appearance.
It was originally planned to build the Crystal Palace in
Madison Square Park, but the protests of residents in that fashionable
neighborhood compelled the abandonment of the scheme. The land in
back of the Croton Reservoir, now Bryant Park, but then known as
Reservoir Square, was leased from the City for a nominal rental of
one dollar a year. Construction work began in 1852, and the building.
housing the first World's Fair to be held in the United States, was
formally opened on July 14, 1853, by President Franklin Pierce.
The building, however, was not a financial success, as its London
predecessor had been. The city took possession in May of 1858, and
on October 5 of that year, while the City Fathers were debating the
question of the removal of the building, and while the annual ex-
position of the American Institute was in progress, fire broke out,
and the building was completely destroyed. The land was then con-
verted by the city into the present Bryant Park.
This is a photograph made for the sake of preservation from
the original, a rare and badly faded photograph, whose plate has
1ong ago been lost. The original is on deposit in the Library.

709489f-a.text:

in both of these views, is standing on the downtown platform
and is viewing northeastward.
No. 1 shows the fore-end of a downtown train and a news-
Nreel photographer making the last journey. No. 2 shows a work
train accumulating the wood benches that were a familiar furnish-
inr of every station. The buildings in the background, line
the east side of Sixth Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Note
the Hippodrome in the 43rd-44th Street block.
March, 1939
Views: 1-2
Vm. Herries

which stood on Wall Street at NasSau, and which became the
property of the Federal government when New York became the
temporary capital of the country, in 1789. President Washing-
ton was inaugulrated on its balcony; and that scene was re-
enacted here in 1932.
